identificationModule.briefTitle: What is the Potential Impact of Reviewing Post-procedure Images With Patients Following Interventional Spine Procedures.
identificationModule.officialTitle: What is the Potential Impact of Reviewing Post-procedure Images With Patients Following Interventional Spine Procedures.

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The purpose of this study is to explore the impact of spine physicians reviewing post-procedural fluoroscopic images with patients. The outcome measure to be assessed will be the potential impact the patient satisfaction and the patient's global impression of change (PGIC) 2 weeks after the spine procedure.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: A spine physician will not discuss images with the first group of participants immediately following their procedure. A spine physician will discuss images with the second group of participants immediately following their procedure.

armGroups.label: Post-Procedural Images Not Discussed with Participants
armGroups.description:
During a lumbar epidural steroid injection under fluoroscopic guidance, images are taken as part of the procedure. Following the procedure, the surgeon who performed it will not discuss the images with the participants in this arm.

If participants request an explanation of the images, they will not be included in the analysis.

armGroups.label: Post-Procedural Images Discussed with Participants
armGroups.description: During a lumbar epidural steroid injection under fluoroscopic guidance, images are taken as part of the procedure. Following the procedure, the surgeon who performed it will discuss the images with the participants in this arm.

interventions.name: Reviewing Imaging with Participant
interventions.description: Post-operatively, the images taken during the procedure will be reviewed with the participant.

primaryOutcomes.description: Patient satisfaction as measured by a modified version of the PGS Questionnaire. The questionnaire is comprised of 9 questions measuring general patient satisfaction with the care experience. Each question is on a scale of 1 (very poor) to 5 (very good). The lowest possible score of the PGS is 9, and the highest possible score is 45. The lower the total score, the poorer the patient's satisfaction, while the higher the score, the higher the patient's satisfaction.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Up to 2 hours following procedure in the post-op area

secondaryOutcomes.description: The PGIC is a scale participants use to rate the level of change they have experienced following treatment. The PGIC is a 7-point scale from 1 (very much better) to 7 (very much worse). After making this selection, participants then rate the percentage of how their condition is following the transforaminal epidural steroid injection compared to before, with 10% being "a little better" and 100% being "very much better."

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Lumbosacral radiculopathy symptoms
* Received transforaminal epidural steroid injection

Exclusion Criteria:

* Patients who will be sedated for transforaminal epidural steroid injection
* Unable to read or understand English-language survey
